net.markenwerk.commons.interfaces

Interface Provider<Product>

  • Type Parameters:
    Product - The type of the values to be provided.
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Producer<Product>

    public interface Provider<Product>
    A Provider provides values of the corresponding product type.

    Implementers may provide a new instance of the product each time create() is called, but aren't required to do so. An instance of the product that has already been returned once, may be returned again for any or all following calls.

    It is therefore not recommended to use Provides for products that are stateful unless the internal state of a values doesn't change the value. It is for example okay to use String as the product type, although instances are stateful (String instances store their hash value after it has been calculated for the first time and are therefore technically stateful), but it is not okay to use Iterator as the product type, because every call to Iterator.next() actually changes the Iterator instance.

    Providers are intended to be used in situation, where a mechanism to retrieve a value is more desirable than having the value from the start. These are usually, but not necessarily, situations where the following two conditions are met.

    • It is not certain that the value will be used.
    • It is likely that it is a costly operation to create the value.

    The second condition may only be true for the first call to create() since Providers are allowed to cache and reuse the value.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Torsten Krause (tk at markenwerk dot net)
    See Also:
    Producer

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Product create()
      Provides a product, This may be a costly operation.

    • Method Detail

      • create

        Product create()
        throws CreationException
        Provides a product, This may be a costly operation.

        Implementers may provide a new instance of the product each time this method is called, but aren't required to do so. An instance of the product that has already been returned once, may be returned again in any or all following calls.

        It lies in the responsibility of the caller, to handle unwanted null-values by replacing them with a sensible default value or throwing a NullPointerException.

        Implementers should catch any exception and wrap them in a CreationException.

        Returns:
        The provided product.
        Throws:
        CreationException - If the provisioning of the product failed.
